Object.Description: CSP-17-DGTC477_V4
Final Tier 4/Stage 4 Isuzu Engine Technical Training

Headings.All: Final Tier 4/Stage 4 Isuzu Engine Technical Training

Object.Description: Notes - Welcome

Text.p: Welcome to the Final Tier 4/Stage 4 Isuzu Engine Technical Training course. This course will help you confidently support Final Tier 4/Stage 4 Isuzu Engines.

Object.Description: Technical Training Objectives

Text.p: By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

Object.Description: Notes - Technical Training Objectives

Text.p: Listed on your screen are the objectives for this lesson. Please take a moment to review them and continue when you are ready.

Object.Description: Engine Model Overview
Notes - Engine Model Overview

Text.p: Listed on your screen are the engine models associated with Final Tier 4 Hitachi excavators. A major difference you can see here, is the ZX300-6 (which replaced the ZX290-5) uses a 7.8 Liter 6HK1 engine rather than the 5.2 liter 4HK1 engine used on the 290.

Object.Description: Engine Overview – New Components – 4HK1

Text.p: 2 Add EGR Temperature Sensor (Inlet and Outlet)

Object.Description: Notes - Engine Overview – New Components – 4HK1

Text.p: To meet Final Tier 4 requirements, the components on the 4HK1 engine, shown here, were updated. These include:
Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) inlet and outlet temperature sensors, which are used to monitor EGR operating parameters and for diagnostic purposes.
The EGR Ratio was tuned to reduce Nox emissions further when compared with IT4 engines.
The Pistons are redesigned to run at a lower compression ratio to facilitate more efficient combustion.
The fuel supply pump was updated to supply the injectors with fuel at 180 Megapascals. On IT4 engines the fuel pressure was 160 Megapascals, and
The fuel injectors were upgraded to match the higher fuel pressure and can be precisely controlled to deliver fuel with multi stage injection.

Object.Description: Engine Overview – New Components – 6HK1
Notes - Engine Overview – New Components – 6HK1

Text.p: 6HK1 engines received similar upgrades as the 4HK1 engines, however the 6HK1 also added a charge air cooler temperature sensor. This sensor monitors intake air temperature to ensure the engine is performing to expectations.

Object.Description: Engine Overview - New Components - 6UZ1
Notes - Engine Overview - New Components - 6UZ1

Text.p: 6UZ1 engines received similar upgrades as the 6HK1, however the injection pressure stayed the same as IT4.

Object.Description: Final Tier 4 Strategy

td.p: NOx reduction to Nitrogen and Water
Reduce excess DEF to Nitrogen and Water

Object.Description: Notes - Final Tier 4 Strategy

Text.p: On the IT4 engines, the aftertreatment device included a Diesel Oxidation Catalyst (DOC) and a Catalyzed Soot Filter (CSF) to remove particulate matter from the exhaust. On FT4 engines, extremely efficient combustion and an improved piston design allows Isuzu engines to burn particulate matter in the cylinder during combustion. This eliminates the need for regenerations or a CSF that was featured on the Interim Tier 4 engines.

During combustion, any unburned fuel is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) by DOC number 1 and DOC number 2. For fuel to be converted into CO2, two reactions must occur. The first reaction occurs in DOC #1 at 120 degrees Celsius (248 degrees Fahrenheit). The second reaction occurs in Doc #2 at 160 degrees Celsius (320 degrees Fahrenheit).

To further reduce NOx, diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) is injected into the exhaust stream, where it decomposes into ammonia. Nitrogen oxides react with the ammonia in an SCR canister consisting of an SCR catalyst and ammonia oxidation catalyst. This reaction forms harmless Nitrogen gas and water vapor, which are expelled through the exhaust pipe.

Object.Description: SCR Dosing System
Notes - SCR Dosing System

Text.p: On the screen are the SCR dosing components.

The Dosing Control Unit (DCU) is a new controller that communicates on a CAN bus to the engine control unit (ECU). It is responsible for controlling DEF defrost cycles, dosing control, and monitoring NOx emissions.

The DEF tank stores DEF and contains a DEF tank header. DEF tanks are constructed of cross-linked high density polyethylene (HDPE). A 25% freeze expansion volume is designed into the tank relative to the fill cap height although DEF expansion volume is typically only 7%. The DEF level sensor does not reach to the absolute bottom of the DEF tank. When the level sensor first reads empty, there should be approximately 10% DEF volume remaining in the tank. When you fill a machine with fuel, fill the DEF tank with DEF as well. Another safety built into the tank design is the filler neck. There is a magnet assembled into the neck on all units. In automated filling pumps, the DEF nozzle will sense the presence of the magnetic field. If that is not sensed then the DEF pump will not operate. The magnet does not mistake proof the use of a manual fill bottle although DEF nozzles and Diesel nozzles are different diameters.

The DEF tank header assembly is comprised of the following components: the DEF level sensor, DEF temperature sensor, electrical connector, coolant tubes, DEF suction/return tubes, DEF quality sensor, tank vent, coolant and DEF fittings and a replaceable screen on the DEF pick up tube.

The DEF level sensor is a reed style float that acts on the center portion of the DEF pick-up tube. At the bottom of the DEF pick-up tube you will find the DEF temperature sensor. The DEF quality sensor measures the ratio of Urea to water in the DEF solution.

The DEF dosing module is responsible for drawing DEF from the reservoir and supplying it to the DEF injector. The dosing unit contains the supply pump, filter, and most of the sensors needed for the DEF system. The service interval for the dosing filter is 3000 hours for the 4HK1 engines and 2000 hours for the 6HK1 engines.

Based on the reading from the DEF quality sensor and the NOx sensor located before the SCR catalyst, the ECM will set the duty cycle for the DEF dosing injector. If the DEF quality is poor, the injector will dose enough DEF to reduce NOx to within acceptable limits, but a higher amount of DEF is consumed.
The coolant control valve opens and closes as needed to circulate warm engine coolant throughout the DEF tank and DEF lines to defrost the DEF.

De-Rate Schedule

td.p: Engine Torque Down and Low Idle
Engine Torque Down and Low Idle

Object.Description: Notes - De-Rate Schedule

Text.p: The EPA has mandated derates for engines being compliant with the Final Tier 4 regulation. These derates are listed on your screen. If level 1 derate becomes active, the ECU will reduce the torque output of the engine by 25%. The machine will still be able to slowly move and dig.
If the operator ignores the warnings for derate #1, the ECU implements a level 2 derate by ramping down engine speed to low idle and torque to 50%.

After the DTCs are repaired, the ECU stops the derate counter and removes the derate. The engine must operate for 40 hours without setting another emission related DTC. If another emission related DTC sets, the ECU will continue the derate counter or implement the level 2 derate immediately.
NOTE: Full power is returned after a key-off / key-on cycle before starting the 10 minute ramp back to the final derate status.
If the machine reaches level 2 derate, it will not be able to move or dig.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – MPDr Machine Connection

Text.p: Purchase KVASER cable from Service Guard

td.p: 5 - USB to Serial Adapter (same as iT4)

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – MPDr Machine Connection

Text.p: MPDr is used to diagnose SCR system related fault codes. In addition to the 6 pin MPDr connector in the cab, another connector has been added which allows the technician to connect directly to the dosing control unit (DCU). This connector is located in the compartment directly behind the cab and requires two new cables for connectivity as shown here. Now let’s take a look at the connection procedure and new tests using MPDr.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – MPDr Machine Connection

Text.p: 1 Main Controller Connection in Cab (Same as iT4)
2 SCR System Controller Connection Behind Cab (New Cables for FT4)

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – MPDr Machine Connection

Text.p: As shown here, there are two options for machine connection. The MC/ECM option should be used when connecting to the six pin connector in the cab (this connection provides the same functionality used for iT4). The DCU option should be selected when connecting to the SCR System Controller discussed on the previous slide. It is found in the compartment behind the cab.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools - SCR System Tests
Notes - Diagnostic Tools - SCR System Tests

Text.p: After a DCU connection has been established with MPDr, there are multiple options to select.

Troubleshooting is used to read and clear DCU related diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs). The active tests, urea water pipe leak test, and the air bleeding from the DEF/ADBlue defrosting piping will be discussed in detail later in this course.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Coolant Air Bleed Test

Headings.All: Diagnostic Tools – Coolant Air Bleed Test

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Coolant Air Bleed Test

Text.p: Use the air bleeding defrosting test, to bleed air from the coolant jacket in the DEF lines. This test operates the coolant control valve for 2 and a half minutes to circulate coolant throughout the DEF tank and lines, it should be performed whenever a DEF line is replaced.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Urea Water Pipe Leak Test

Headings.All: Diagnostic Tools – Urea Water Pipe Leak Test

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Urea Water Pipe Leak Test

Text.p: The Urea Water Pipe Leak Test is used to test for leaks in the DEF system. This test will operate the dosing pump inside the dosing module, until the test is stopped by a technician. Follow the onscreen instructions and verify the DEF/ADBlue pressure remains between 800 and 1000 megapascals. If the pressure drops below 800 megapascals, perform the test again and inspect the system for switched lines or leaks.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Active Tests
Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Active Tests

Text.p: The active tests, check operation of the dosing injector, coolant control valve, and reversing valve. Select any of the tests from the Function, engine, active tests menu in MPDr.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Operation of Dosing Valve

Headings.All: Diagnostic Tools – Operation of Dosing Valve

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Operation of Dosing Valve

Text.p: The Operation of Dosing Valve Test is used to manually verify proper operation of the DEF dosing system components. It will operate the dosing system to ensure DEF can be delivered to the SCR catalyst. This is the most comprehensive DEF system test and should be performed if an aftertreatment system fault is activated. This test is performed with the ignition ON and the engine OFF.
During this test, verify the Dosing Valve Status reaches a value greater than 40 cycles as shown on the screen.
Note: After this test is complete, start and operate the engine to remove any residual DEF from the decomposition tube. This will prevent DEF deposit formation.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Coolant Control Valve

Headings.All: Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Coolant Control Valve

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Coolant Control Valve

Text.p: The Operation Check of Coolant Control Valve Test has 2 separate options and uses. If you select “Start (One Time)”, the coolant control valve will open and remain open for 60 seconds. If there is an active DTC, indicating the DEF temperature is too high, it is likely the coolant control valve may be stuck open. Perform this test to flush the coolant control valve and clear any debris that might be blocking it open.

Select “Start (Continuous)” to test operation of the coolant control valve. It will open and close every 5 seconds for a total of 60 seconds. This should be used to verify the coolant control valve is operating properly.

Object.Description: Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Reverting Valve

Headings.All: Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Reverting Valve

Object.Description: Notes - Diagnostic Tools – Operation Check of Reverting Valve

Text.p: The Operation Check of Reverting Valve Test has 2 separate options and uses. If you select “Start (One Time)”, the reversing valve located in the DEF dosing module will open and remain open for 60 seconds. Perform this test to flush debris from the reversing valve.

Select “Start (Continuous)” to test operation of the reversing valve. It will open and close every 5 seconds for a total of 60 seconds. This should be used to verify the reversing valve is operating properly.

Object.Description: Cold Weather Feature – Fuel Recirculation
Notes - Cold Weather Feature – Fuel Recirculation

Text.p: A fuel recirculation system was added to FT4 Isuzu Engines to prevent fuel gelling in the main fuel filter during cold weather operation. A thermostat was added to the fuel filter/water separator housing that stays closed until return fuel reaches a warm temperature. While the fuel is cold, warm return oil is circulated back into the main filter and fuel system without returning to the tank.
